skill.name: browser-automation
skill.description: Enterprise-grade browser automation using WebDriver protocol. Use when the user needs to automate web browsers, perform web scraping, test web applications, fill forms, take screenshots, monitor performance, or execute multi-step browser workflows. Supports Chrome, Firefox, and Edge with connection pooling and health management.
skill.summary: Enterprise browser automation using WebDriver protocol for web scraping, form filling, testing, and multi-step browser workflows.
skill.author: EmilLindfors

security_audit.summary: The static analyzer detected 379 potential issues across documentation and example files. After evaluation, all findings are FALSE_POSITIVES - patterns appear in documentation examples, not executable code. The skill is a legitimate browser automation tool using WebDriver protocol with no malicious intent or exploitable vulnerabilities.

high_findings.title: Shell Command Execution Patterns in Documentation
high_findings.description: The static analyzer detected Ruby/shell backtick syntax in 298 locations across documentation files. These patterns appear in markdown code blocks within example documentation files.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: All detected patterns are within markdown documentation files, specifically in code block examples showing shell command syntax. These are documentation artifacts, not executable code that could be exploited.

high_findings.title: Weak Cryptographic Algorithm Usage
high_findings.description: The static analyzer flagged MD5 usage as 'weak cryptographic algorithm' across multiple documentation files.
high_findings.confidence_reasoning: MD5 references appear to be checksum examples or documentation of file integrity verification, not cryptographic operations protecting sensitive data. No evidence of MD5 being used for password hashing, token generation, or security-critical operations.

medium_findings.title: Hardcoded URLs in Documentation
medium_findings.description: The static analyzer detected hardcoded URLs across documentation files. These are legitimate example URLs used in documentation.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: URLs in documentation are example targets for web scraping and automation testing. These are not credential exfiltration endpoints or command-and-control servers.

medium_findings.title: Temporary Directory Access
medium_findings.description: The static analyzer detected temp directory access patterns across multiple files.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Temp file operations are standard practice for storing screenshots, downloads, and session data in browser automation workflows. No evidence of path traversal attacks or malicious file operations.

medium_findings.title: System Reconnaissance Patterns
medium_findings.description: The static analyzer flagged system command usage as 'system reconnaissance' in web scraping examples.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: System commands in examples are for checking browser installation status, not network scanning or reconnaissance. Legitimate diagnostic usage for browser automation setup.

low_findings.title: Python Environment Access
low_findings.description: The static analyzer detected Python environment access in setup scripts.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Environment access is for reading configuration variables in setup scripts. No evidence of credential theft or secret exfiltration.

low_findings.title: Standard Device File Access
low_findings.description: The static analyzer detected device file access in setup scripts.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Device file access is for standard Unix operations like /dev/null and null device redirection. Legitimate script behavior, not malicious.

dangerous_patterns.title: Critical Heuristic: Code Execution + Network + Credential Access
dangerous_patterns.description: The static analyzer flagged a dangerous combination pattern: code execution, network access, and credential access appearing together.
dangerous_patterns.confidence_reasoning: These patterns appear across separate documentation sections and setup scripts, not combined in an exploitable attack chain. The skill is a browser automation tool that legitimately requires network access and local command execution. No evidence of malicious intent or data exfiltration.

dangerous_patterns.title: Heuristic: Filesystem + Credentials + Network
dangerous_patterns.description: The static analyzer flagged a suspicious combination of filesystem access, credentials, and network access.
dangerous_patterns.confidence_reasoning: Setup scripts legitimately read configuration, access filesystem, and make network requests for browser driver downloads. Standard development practice, not malicious behavior.

content.value_statement: Manual browser testing and web scraping are time-consuming and error-prone. This skill provides enterprise-grade browser automation using WebDriver protocol, enabling reliable form filling, screenshot capture, performance monitoring, and multi-step web workflows across Chrome, Firefox, and Edge.
actual_capabilities: Navigate to URLs and manage browser sessions with connection pooling
Fill and submit web forms with automatic element detection
Capture full-page and element screenshots for visual testing
Execute JavaScript and evaluate page performance metrics
Handle multi-step workflows with implicit and explicit waits
Scrape dynamic content from JavaScript-heavy websites
limitations: Requires separate WebDriver server installation for target browsers
Cannot automate browser extensions or developer tools directly
Limited support for browser-specific features outside WebDriver spec
Performance varies based on browser choice and system resources

use_cases.title: Automated end-to-end testing
use_cases.description: QA engineers use this skill to create reliable browser tests that verify web application functionality across different browsers without manual intervention.
use_cases.target_user: QA engineers and test automation developers

use_cases.title: Web data extraction at scale
use_cases.description: Data engineers and researchers automate scraping of dynamic websites that require JavaScript rendering, extracting structured data for analysis pipelines.

use_cases.title: Automated form processing
use_cases.description: Business users automate repetitive web-based form submissions, data entry tasks, and workflow processes that span multiple web pages.

prompt_templates.title: Basic browser navigation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the browser automation skill to navigate to https://example.com and tell me what the page title is.

prompt_templates.title: Form submission automation
prompt_templates.prompt: Go to the login page at https://example.com/login, fill in the username field with 'testuser' and password field with 'password123', then click the submit button and report the result.

prompt_templates.title: Screenshot capture
prompt_templates.prompt: Navigate to https://example.com/dashboard, wait for the page to fully load (5 seconds), and take a full-page screenshot saved to /tmp/dashboard.png. Report the file path when complete.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-step workflow automation
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform the following multi-step workflow: 1) Go to https://example.com/shop, 2) Search for 'wireless headphones', 3) Click on the first product, 4) Add it to cart, 5) Navigate to cart page, 6) Take screenshot of cart contents. Report each step result.

output_examples.input: Navigate to https://example.com and find all heading elements on the page.
Fill out the contact form at https://example.com/contact with name='John Doe', email='john@example.com', and message='Hello World', then submit it.
output: Confirmation message: 'Thank you for your message!'

output_examples.input: Check the page load performance of https://example.com by measuring JavaScript execution time and reporting core web vitals.

best_practices: Use explicit waits with timeout settings instead of fixed sleep delays for reliable element detection across different page load speeds.
Keep browser drivers updated to match browser versions for compatibility and security patches.
Store screenshots and downloads in designated directories with proper cleanup to avoid disk space issues during long-running automations.
anti_patterns: Avoid hardcoding selectors without fallback strategies - page structure changes will break your automations.
Do not skip error handling for network timeouts and element not found exceptions - these are common in real-world web automation.
Avoid running multiple browser instances without connection pooling in production environments to prevent resource exhaustion.

faq.question: What browsers are supported by this skill?
faq.answer: This skill supports Chrome, Firefox, and Edge browsers through WebDriver protocol. Each browser requires a compatible WebDriver binary installed separately on your system.

faq.question: How do I install WebDriver for my browser?
faq.answer: Download the appropriate WebDriver (ChromeDriver for Chrome, GeckoDriver for Firefox, or EdgeDriver for Edge) from the official vendor websites. Place it in your system PATH or configure the location in skill settings.

faq.question: Can this skill handle CAPTCHA or bot protection?
faq.answer: No, this skill cannot bypass CAPTCHA, reCAPTCHA, or other bot protection mechanisms. These require external services or manual intervention.

faq.question: How do I handle dynamic content that loads asynchronously?
faq.answer: Use explicit waits with element presence or visibility conditions instead of fixed sleep timers. The skill provides wait_for_element functions that poll until the element is ready.

faq.question: What happens if a page element is not found?
faq.answer: The skill will raise an ElementNotFound error by default. Wrap operations in try-catch blocks to handle these gracefully, or use the wait_for_element functions that include timeout handling.

faq.question: Can I run this skill in headless mode?
faq.answer: Yes, configure the browser initialization with headless=true option for server environments or CI/CD pipelines where graphical display is not available.
